body: If there are blocking questions, then they should block the generation of the procedure so that the ai doesn't go barking up the wrong tree. This relates to the GitHub Issue about modifying questions to have the answers be pre defined so the user just has to select the relevant answers. Questions should be critical for determining the type of procedure. Asking if they have the color of paint to fix the chipped wall is not a good question because it should instead be a procedure item that occurs after the identification of the color of paint. If the user already has it then they can immediately check off the step in the procedure.
title: Questions before procedure

body: if a capture is typed as an issue then it will create an issue instance, the data is sent to the ai with a tailored promt, any required questions will be generated, and eventually a procedure with required items is generated. If it is typed as inventory, then the ai will identify the items in the image and those items will be added to the inventory or have the quantity updated. A cleaning type might be a sub type of an issue and not change the structure but just be appended to the data sent to the ai helping it understand the context.
title: Typed capture dictates flow

body:
behavioural + layout consistency:
	•	Event handling – Every list cell currently re-implements onPress, onSwipe, “long-press to multi-select”, etc. A single <ListItem> HOC lets you wire those once and pass the variant (Issue / To-Do / To-Get) as props.
	•	Spacing & typography – Even with a shared colour/radius token, padding and font sizes vary (check commit a2f6…) and that breaks visual rhythm.
	•	Future refactors – When you introduce animated reorder or drag-and-drop, doing it in one wrapper is dramatically simpler.
title: List component

body:
## Trade:
<head></head>
Pros | Cons
-- | --
Far fewer “camera killed” events on Android | Requires eject’ing if you’re on Expo’s managed workflow
Ultra‑low latency previews & flexible frame processing | Larger native footprint, more dependencies
First‑class support for advanced vision/ML use cases | Slightly steeper install & upgrade path

## Process
- Setup & Install: (eject, pods, 
- API Rewrite (replace preview, capture flow, adapt taps)
- Frame Processor Worklets (optional)

body: Encapsulate motion‑threshold logic in a hook (useDualCapture) that automatically cleans up subscriptions.

comments.body:
With the latest changes, we’ve fully extracted and encapsulated your tap‑to‑capture logic along with sensor data handling into a dedicated custom hook, useDualCapture. Here’s a concise recap of what was achieved:
	1.	Modular Dual‑Capture Logic
	•	All of the “first tap → wait for motion threshold or 5 s timeout → second shot → optional AI analysis” behavior now lives in useDualCapture, rather than inline in CameraScreen.
	•	This hook cleanly manages:
	•	Initiating the first photo and recording its URI, timestamp, and GPS.
	•	Subscribing to device motion to detect a rotation beyond the threshold.
	•	Falling back to a 5 s timer if no motion event occurs.
	•	Taking the second photo and recording its data.
	•	Triggering AI analysis when enabled.
	2.	Proper Setup & Teardown
	•	The hook sets the motion‐sensor update interval appropriately.
	•	All subscriptions and timers are automatically cleaned up on unmount, preventing memory leaks or “zombie” listeners.
	3.	Type Safety & Null‑Safety
	•	The cameraRef parameter in the hook signature was updated to RefObject<CameraViewType | null>, matching how it’s declared in the component.
	•	We added non‑null assertions (cameraRef.current!) around takePictureAsync calls so TypeScript no longer complains about possible null refs.
	4.	Clear Component Code
	•	CameraScreen is now focused solely on UI concerns—rendering the camera preview, handling permissions, and presenting loading/error feedback—while all capture sequencing lives in the hook.
	•	This separation dramatically improves readability, testability, and maintainability.

All of the “first tap → motion‑threshold or timeout → second tap” logic has been extracted into the useDualCapture hook, which sets up DeviceMotion, Accelerometer, and Barometer listeners (using DeviceMotion.addListener), and automatically cleans them up (and any pending timeouts) on unmount

milestone.title: Stabilization and Hardening
milestone.description: Remove prototype smells—no secrets in JS, add persistence, robust async error handling, clean up sensors, tighten typings.

title: Sensor data management

body: Add storage layer (e.g. AsyncStorage, SQLite).

comments.body:
I’ve wired up AsyncStorage persistence:
	•	Imported AsyncStorage from @react-native-async-storage/async-storage.
	•	Rehydration: on app start, we load and parse stored issues into state.
	•	Persistence: any time issues changes, we serialize and save it.
The AppInner component now uses AsyncStorage to rehydrate captured issues on app launch (getItem('issues')) and persist any changes immediately via setItem('issues', JSON.stringify(issues))

milestone.title: Stabilization and Hardening
milestone.description: Remove prototype smells—no secrets in JS, add persistence, robust async error handling, clean up sensors, tighten typings.

title: App Persistance

body: Entire analysis lives in the camera component; consider extracting an analysisService or custom hook (useIssueAnalysis) to decouple UI from networking.

comments.body:
Pulled the AI networking logic out of CameraScreen into a standalone useIssueAnalysis hook. Now:
	•	useIssueAnalysis lives above your screens, keeping network/fetch logic separate from UI.
	•	CameraScreen simply calls useIssueAnalysis(recordIssue) to get analyzeIssue.
	•	useDualCapture still orchestrates capture flow, now unburdened by networking code.
The previous inline fetch logic in CameraScreen has been moved into a standalone useIssueAnalysis hook. CameraScreen now simply calls analyzeIssue(), keeping networking/fetch code out of the UI layer

milestone.title: Stabilization and Hardening
milestone.description: Remove prototype smells—no secrets in JS, add persistence, robust async error handling, clean up sensors, tighten typings.

title: decouple UI from networking

body:
The Issue type is defined inline and assumed complete after initial capture; partial updates rely on type coercion (as Issue).
Opportunity: Split Issue into IssueCapture vs IssueAnalysis; leverage discriminated unions so TS can enforce required vs optional fields.

comments.body:
Refactored Issue type into three distinct interfaces—IssueBase, IssueWithSecond, and IssueWithAnalysis—and then unified them under a discriminated type Issue. This gives you compile‑time clarity on which fields are present at each lifecycle stage (initial capture, second shot, and post-analysis).
Couple errors initially popped-up but fixed it with:
I added two type guards (isIssueWithSecond, isIssueWithAnalysis) and updated IssueDetailScreen to:
	•	Only render the second image if issue has secondUri.
	•	Only access analysis after narrowing with isIssueWithAnalysis.
	•	Fix implicit-any by typing the .map callbacks (step: string, i: number, q: string, i: number).

We now have three explicit interfaces—IssueBase, IssueWithSecond, and IssueWithAnalysis—unified into a discriminated union Issue, plus type‑guard functions (isIssueWithSecond, isIssueWithAnalysis) that let TS enforce when fields like secondUri or analysis are safe to access

labels.name: Risk
labels.description: Tag for something that has a likelihood and criticality

milestone.title: Stabilization and Hardening
milestone.description: Remove prototype smells—no secrets in JS, add persistence, robust async error handling, clean up sensors, tighten typings.

title: TypeScript typings

body:
Most async calls (takePictureAsync, Location.getCurrentPositionAsync, fetch) lack try/catch beyond the AI block.
Result: A camera error or network failure can crash the app or leave the UI frozen without feedback.

comments.body:
- You now wrap every analyzeIssue call in a try/catch/finally.
- Errors bubble up into a user‑facing banner ({errorMsg && …}) and all spinners are cleared in the finally, preventing any hung loading state.
- That meets the goal of giving users clear feedback on success, failure, and completion of the AI call.

All AI analysis calls are wrapped in try/catch/finally via wrappedAnalyzeIssue, with setErrorMsg on failure and setLoading(false) in finally. The UI shows an error banner when errorMsg is set and always clears spinners afterward

labels.name: Risk
labels.description: Tag for something that has a likelihood and criticality

milestone.title: Stabilization and Hardening
milestone.description: Remove prototype smells—no secrets in JS, add persistence, robust async error handling, clean up sensors, tighten typings.

title: Async Error handling & UX states

body:
Subscriptions for DeviceMotion / Accelerometer / Barometer are registered in effects, but teardown logic is sometimes missing (e.g., the motion‐threshold listener may not always be removed if unmounted mid‑capture).
Risk: Memory leaks, zombie listeners draining battery.

comments.body: Encapsulated your accelerometer and barometer subscriptions in a new useSensorData hook with proper cleanup, removed the old inline subscription code, and added a top-level cleanup effect to clear any pending motion-threshold listeners or timeouts on component unmount.

labels.name: Risk
labels.description: Tag for something that has a likelihood and criticality

title: Sensor & subscription cleanup

body:
Uses a single React useState<Issue[]> in App to hold all captured issues.
Risk: Lacks persistence (everything is in‑memory), no offline/restore capability.

labels.name: Risk
labels.description: Tag for something that has a likelihood and criticality

title: State management

body:
All screens and core logic (camera, sensor subscriptions, AI analysis) live in one file.
Risk: Growing complexity → maintenance burden, merge conflicts, difficulty testing.
## Judgment
This is an acceptable risk for the benefit of enabling efficient collaboration with LLMs that benefit from monolithic codebases.

comments.body: A trigger for review of the judgement might be if collaboration with other code contributors looks imminent.
Split out into smaller issues after oboe started failing in the large App.tsx

labels.name: Risk
labels.description: Tag for something that has a likelihood and criticality

title: Single App.tsx

body:
What should the project guidence be for when to make or use a GitHub label, milestone, or project? 
## Label
- Unique to repository
- Multiple can be assigned to an issue
### Use Cases of labels
- Categorize: Action required

## Milestone
- One per issue
- Time bound
- Can be linked to pull requests
- Issues can be prioritized with-in the milestone
### Use Cases of Milestones
- Sprints
- Work packages

## Project
- Issue can be assigned to multiple projects (I think)
- Issue have [fields](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-projects/understanding-fields) unique to project
- Can group issues and pull requests
- Use views to save preset filters
- Can have [iterations](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-projects/understanding-fields/about-iteration-fields)?
- Can have [road maps](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-projects/customizing-views-in-your-project/customizing-the-roadmap-layout)
### Use Cases of projects
- Allow independent working groups 
- Should include field that indicates how a Project is a stakeholder in the issue (RACI)
title: When to use a milestone vs. a label vs. a project

body: Don't ship the api key in the app at runtime.

comments.body: Not worrying about this until MVP is defined and closer to reality.
It is actually nice to have it in the code base while prototyping and collaborating.

body: Angie's list, task rabbit, every to do list ever, any ERP or FMS, yelp, fiver, Amazon, SeeClickFix. Address is at an intersection of all of these trying to connect the user, manager, and technician in a manner that creates value for everyone.
title: Why hasn't this been done before?

body: Could go to advertising, sponsored integration with Walmart, Kroger, etc.
title: Path: Excellent issue management

body:
Could focusing just on issue capture and facilitating high quality inspection from novices be a market? Touring potential purchases and rentals such as apartments, hotels, homes, cars, equipment. 
This would be a lead in to Procedural and robust feed of review data.
title: Are inspections a market?

body: Who are the stakeholders, what are the use cases, requirements, and competitors.
title: Is "Honey Do" a market?

body: Build an API that is able to post issues and updates to them and get  updates from posted issues.
title: API for issue Get and Post

body: Use the same method for capturing an issue to capture images of their inventory and index them using an AI. This should enable bulk import to the inventory
title: Add to inventory from capture session

body: Allow users to add items to inventory list of equipment and materials that are available to them. When equipment or materials reach their repurchase threshold the user puts them on the to acquire list. Once an item is acquired it moves to inventory list. This can be done on the List screen. Allow users to add items to the To Get list and if the item is checked then it is in the inventory. These are all material/equipment tags so new additions should be added to the tag pool and intern populate as tag suggestions. It would be great if when a user went to add to the To Get list it auto filled so they could select tags that already exist and update the status on them or remind themselves of the status, in the later case it should just shuffle the order of the item so the existing item appears where they expect.
title: Assemble inventory

body:
GitHub, Jira, Trello, etc. could be the web interface for facilities to manage, delegate, and resolve issues. This would reduce the development burden significantly. 
GitHub is my preference because of CLI, possibly to store procedures as documents, scripts, or "Actions".

## Potential trade criteria 
- Object management 
- API
- web interface 
- Mobile app
- Pricing
- Longevity/maintaince
title: How could an existing service be the web interface for facilities?

body: Get ChatGPT to parse the notes into new features, questions, and wontfix Upload the issues though gh cli. Triage issues in GitHub.
title: Important issues from Obsidian

body:
Issues from customers, passersby, and other transient stakeholders face the issue of routing them to the responsible party. Renters may be able to hand over an export of the issues but it could be rejected because it wasn't submitted through the established portal. 
Capturing the location of the issue means it is possible to find the owner of the land and potentially the responsible party of the facility by sending mail, internet sleuthing, and the like. 
For a service like this to be dominant it would need an api and web app for facility managers to tap into to view and triage issues.
title: Is it worth it to capture non-resident issues

body: Is it possible to have enough people on the app and capturing issues so that a technician that is going to be in the area is provided with a menu of jobs that they could pair to maximize time being paid versus travel, sales, etc. With Al of the prerequisite questions, material, and equipment identified and maybe already acquired.
title: How to maximize technicians time

body: Issues of items like software and things that can move or be moved. This requires knowing the responsible party (implicitly or explicitly) and vendor/manufacturer.
title: Non-facility issues worth it?

body: Ai should suggest a 2 to 4 word title that can be modified by the user

milestone.title: UX/UI Sprint May 2025
milestone.description: Getting things working and looking smooth 😎

title: Swipe from capture screen

body: Add a dark mode toggle and match phone mode.

comments.body: The manual override for light/dark mode is now loaded from and saved to AsyncStorage, and the app honors it over the system scheme. With system listening still intact, automatic changes work too.

•	Defined a Design Token set
	•	Created lightTheme & darkTheme objects (colors, spacing, radii, fontSizes)
	•	Bundled them in a ThemeContext with a toggleTheme() stub
	•	Built a ThemeProvider
	•	Listened to Appearance for system color‑scheme changes
	•	Loaded/saved a manual override (themeOverride) from AsyncStorage
	•	Computed effectiveScheme = manualScheme ?? systemScheme and exposed { theme, toggleTheme }
	•	Hooked into React
	•	Exported useTheme() to read theme & call toggleTheme() anywhere
	•	Wrapped the App
	•	Split out the old App() into an inner AppInner()
	•	Exported a new App() that renders <ThemeProvider><AppInner/></ThemeProvider>
	•	Synced Navigation
	•	Imported RN‑Navigation’s Default/Dark themes
	•	In AppInner, built a navigationTheme by merging the chosen theme colors
	•	Passed it to <NavigationContainer theme={navigationTheme}>
	•	Added screenOptions on each stack to use headerStyle.backgroundColor = theme.colors.card and headerTintColor = theme.colors.text
	•	Styled the bottom‑tab bar’s activeTintColor, inactiveTintColor, and backgroundColor from theme.colors
	•	Themed Each Screen
	•	CameraScreen: wrapped root <View> and “waiting…” <Text> in theme.colors.background/.text
	•	IssuesScreen: set <FlatList> background and each timestamp/coord <Text> to theme.colors.text
	•	IssueDetailScreen: set <ScrollView> background and all metadata/analysis <Text> to theme.colors.text
	•	Default Behavior
	•	On first load, app picks up the device’s dark/light setting
	•	Users can flip the “Dark Mode” switch in Settings to override

title: Dark mode

body: When holding the phone a capture event triggers due to the very edge of the screen registering a tap. Proposed solution is to create an offset around the edge of the screen. maybe about a 1/4 of an inch buffer?

comments.body: Edge taps are now filtered out in the capture hook, and the Pressable touch area uses a 20 px hitSlop so only deliberate taps register.

milestone.title: UX/UI Sprint May 2025
milestone.description: Getting things working and looking smooth 😎

title: Inadvertent captures

body:
30 degrees might not be the correct trigger. It may be that rotation of the phone doesn't matter as much as translation . A different angle might not be as useful as an establishment and closeup shot pair. What if we were able to give the user agency in deciding which is best while still having an auto trigger for the second photo?
Instead of a static rotation/movement limit what if it sensed if a movement started and waits for a pause or if the subject is suspected to leave the frame in the next half second. This could be done by assuming a worse case initial distance (~ 6 inches) and take the initial tap location to triangulate the rotation trigger dynamically. It does require estimating the device FOV.

comments.body: Still need to tune parameters with multiple people.

title: Second perspective trigger

body: After using the app on and off for 5 hours I noticed that when I tapped on the screen it didn't flash and when I checked the issue list screen it didn't show the new issues. When I restarted the expo project and loaded it on my phone with the qr code it resumed working.

comments.body: Presumed memory issue with sensors and unlimited subscription. Presumed Fixed

body:
In the Capture Screen the user should be able to select one or more tags for the issues captured in the session to be automatically tagged under.
e.g.:
chores" and  "cleaning" could be selected as tags so that all issues captured in that session would be tagged as chores and cleaning.
Potential be step: what if "issue" was a tag and the prompt and schema for the issue detail screen was linked to it. That way maybe inventory could be a tag that was captured by the camera
title: Select Tags for Capture Session
